instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3476: What is 820-3476? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL: What is PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL? This is the voltage coming directly from the charger after going through a transistor. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: No powering up. Missing <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Hello

Have a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not power up. No sign of liquid damage. Here are readings have taken so far:

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> - 12.59
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL</SIGNAL> - 16.69
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> - 3.42
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> - 3.34
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> - 5.01
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> - 0 but also pulsing

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> - 3.34
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> - 3.34

<SIGNAL>PCH_CLK32K_RTCX1</SIGNAL> - 32.77KHz
<SIGNAL>SYSCLK_CLK25M_CAMERA</SIGNAL> - no sig
<SIGNAL>SYSCLK_CLK25M_TBT</SIGNAL> - no sig

Any suggestions on what else i could check. 

Thanks

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: No powering up. Missing <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
I did just ran into weird issue, using a MedUSA, i noticed that it wasn't able to read a serial number off the board, and said that the Sys block was missing. So i pulled the chip and extracted the bios from it and confirmed that the serial number was present. So, decide to try a different bios file. while trying to flash the bios chip with a bios from another machine using MedUSA it got locked at 18% and now the board is running (haven't tested with a display, but it chimes on). Not confident that it's fully fixed and now I can't read the chip using the medusa.

Going to refresh the chip with a clean bios file

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: No powering up. Missing <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Ok, seems refreshing the chip fixed it. But still can't flash using the MedUSA. Everything seems to run just fine.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: No powering up. Missing <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Medusa fails to write sometime...
You must pull the chip then and solder it on A4064 adapter.
Medusa will do its job there.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: No powering up. Missing <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Yeah that's pretty much what i did. I've ran the laptop for for about and hour and without issues.
